explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to check the MISRA rule (A function parameter should not be modified):

- sysctlbyname: The function calls sysctlbyname in several places. To be sure the target function itself does not modify any of its own parameters via macro expansion or side effects, the analyser needs the declaration/definition of sysctlbyname (it could be a macro or inline wrapper that alters surrounding code).

- sysctl: Same reason as sysctlbyname; the call to sysctl must be known (or ruled out) to ensure no hidden macro expands into code that would modify parameters of the target function.

- __linux__: Controls conditional compilation of almost the entire function body. Whether __linux__ is defined changes which code is present; the analyser must know the active compilation path to determine whether any code that could modify parameters is present.

- HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME: Controls inclusion of blocks that call sysctlbyname. The analyser must know if those blocks are compiled in.

- HAVE_SYSCTL: Controls inclusion of blocks that call sysctl. Needed to know whether those calls (or related code) are present in the compiled function.

- HAS_DECL_CTL_HW, HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE, HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU: These macros control inclusion of the sysctl() MIB-based code paths (using CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE, HW_AVAILCPU). The analyser must know which of these conditional blocks are active.

- CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE, HW_AVAILCPU: These macros are used to build the mib[] array passed to sysctl. If any are macros that expand to complex expressions or functions, they could affect whether the function modifies any of its own parameters via macro expansion—so their definitions are required.

- size_t: The code declares and uses size_t variables (value_size). Knowing the typedef/definition ensures there are no surprising macro tricks that could change the semantics of those declarations and thus affect whether parameters are modified.

Note: The target function itself has no formal parameters (void). The above symbols are requested so the analyser can determine the exact compiled body (via conditional macros) and ensure no called function or macro expansion introduces code that would modify formal parameters of the target function (or transform the function signature).
